required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Evaluation of the Optimum Brushing Force on Dental Plaque Removal and the Abrasive Effect of Brushing Force on Enamel Surface.
clinical_study.official_title: Evaluation of the Optimum Brushing Force on Dental Plaque Removal and the Abrasive Effect of Brushing Force on Enamel Surface: An in Vitro Study.

brief_summary.textblock:
Objective
1. To determine the optimum brushing force for dental plaque removal.
2. To investigate the effect of brushing force on enamel characteristic.
Hypothesis H0 : Structural tooth loss is not significantly different between before and after brushing with excessive force on enamel surface.
H1 : Structural tooth loss is significantly different between before and after brushing with excessive force on enamel surface.
Study design: Experimental study

primary_outcome.description: The toothbrush holder was adjusted allowing toothbrush bristle to press onto the tooth surface until the loading monitor indicated the designated vertical loading force. Loading force was applied from a minimum of 1 N, with an increment of 1 N to a maximum of 6 N. The optimum force which remove all dental plaque from tooth surface will recorded.

clinical_study.condition: the Optimum Brushing Force for Dental Plaque Removal and the Effect of Brushing Force on Enamel Characteristic

intervention.description: Using duplication method, vertical force was applied from 1-5.5 N in linear mesial-distal brushing motion at 4 strokes per second for 5 seconds Force was increase 0.5 N in every testing until plaque was completely removed from enamel surface

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- extracted bovine incisors
Exclusion Criteria:
- no

overall_official.affiliation: Department of Oral Medicine and Periodontology, Faculty of Dentistry, Mahidol University, Bangkok Thailand
